coredata.dc:title: Avoiding the integral storage bottleneck in LCAO calculations of electron correlation
coredata.dc:creator: Sæbø, Svein
Almlöf, Jan
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We propose a method for obtaining electron-repulsion integrals over a molecular-orbital basis without any explicit four-index transformation involving input/output. The approach is in the spirit of our direct SCF scheme in that it uses reevaluation of atomic integrals to allow for calculations that would otherwise be prohibited by storage limitations with conventional techniques. We present correlation energy calculations with up to 318 basis functions using the proposed approach.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 154, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 6 January 1989 AN ANISOTROPIC HYPERNETIED CHAIN APPROXIMATION FOR THE SPHERICAL CELL MODEL M. FUSHIKI Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606. Japan Received 9 September 1988; in final form 14September 1982 The anisotropic hypernetted chain approximation is applied to the spherical cell model. The osmotic pressure obtained with this approximation is different from that of the nonlinear Poisson Boltzmann equation, and agrees well with the result of Monte Carlo simulations, especially for a system of divalent counterions. 1. Introduction The Poisson Boltzmann (PB) cell model is widely used to investigate the static structure of polyelectrolyte solutions [1 3], such as micellar solutions, colloidal suspensions and some biological systems. It has already been pointed out, however, that correlation between small ions has been neglected in this approximation [4,5], causing some discrepancies between its results and those of Monte Carlo simulations [6 8]. Several analytical attempts have been made [9,10] to improve this defect. Among these, Kjellander and Mareelja [101 intro- duced the anisotropic hypernetted chain (AHNC) equation to the ion distribution between two planar sur- faces, and obtained a double-layer force which agreed well with the MC result. In this Letter we apply their method to a spherical cell model and obtain the osmotic pressure for this system. 2. Method Let us consider a salt-free polyelectrolyte solution. The system consists of polyions p and counterions c of diamete a, charge Z, and number density n1. In the cell model, a polyion is situated at the center of the spherical cell of radius r5 (4x/3r~ w = and becomes a source of an external field for the counterions, ssu~~(r)=ZPZCL /r, r a~~=1(c~+c~) =oo, r<c~, (1) where sslfkT and L~=e2/ekTis the Bjerrum length (we set e=78.3 and T=298 K so that LB= 7.16 A). On the other hand, N~ (= Z~/Z~) counterions contained in this cell interact with each other via the potential ssu(r)=Z~L07r, r~u~~=a, (2) In this work, we regard counterions as point charges for simplicity. As the simplest approximation for this model, we can obtain the ion distribution function n (r) by solving O 009-26141891$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. 77 (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume t 54, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6 January 1989 the PB equation. This equation can be obtained if we neglect the two-particle correlation function in the Yvon hierarchy [5], V1ln[n(r1)J=V,ssu~~(r1)+ f [Vtu(rl,r2)]n~1~ydr2~Vtssupc(r,)+ f [V,u(r1,r2)]n(r2)dr2, (3) where the two-particle distribution function n (r1, r2) is related to the radial distribution function and the total correlation function by n(rl,r2) n(rl)n(r2)g(rI,r2)=n(r3n(r2)[l+h(r1,r2)], so that g(r,, r2)=l, or h(r,, r2)=O in the PB approximation. Thus, information on the total correlation function is necessary to improve the PB approximation. To obtain this function, we solve the following AHNC equation [11]. On the one hand, if the one-particle density n (r) is given, h (r1, r2) is determined by the anisotropic Ornstein Zernicke (AOZ) equation h(r1, r2) =c(r1, r2)+ j n(r3) c(r,, r3) h(r3, ~2) dr3 (4) and the HNC closure relation c(r1,r2)=exp[y(r1,r2) ssu(Ir, r21)] y(r,,r2) l, (5) where c(r,, r2) is the two-particle direct correlation function and y(r,, r2) h(r1, r2) c(r1, r2) is the nodal function. On the other hand, if the solutions of eqs. (4) and (5) are obtained, the one-particle density n (r) would be determined by eq. (3). Within the HNC approximation, however, this n (r) is given more easily by [11] n(r)=~exp{ ss[u0~(r)+W(r)]}, (6) ssW(r,)= J n(r2) (~[h(r,,r2)]2 c(r,,r2)}dr2+c(r,,r2)+l. (7) We can obtain a final solution by a double iterative procedure [11] for the set of equations (4) and (5) and eq. (6). These equations, so far, have been written in a general form. Let us rewrite them in a suitable form for the spherical geometry. In this case, the two-particle correlation functions are specified with three coordinates, the radial distances of particle 1 and 2, r,= 1r11, and the cosine between r, and r2, u12. The AOZ equation (5) is then h(r1, r2, u,2) =c(r1, r2, u,2) + J n(r3) r~ dr3 J c(r,, r2, u12) h(r,, r2, u,2) du3 (8) where du3 denotes the infinitesimal solid angle element for particle 3. This function is transformed by relation (9), and the new estimate of c(r1, r2, u,2) is obtained from it using eq. (5). In the actual calculation, the summation over / of eq. (9) has been truncated at 1m3~= 10, and angular in- tegration of eq. (10) is performed by Gaussian integration [12] using 32 mesh points. The number of mesh points for the radial coordinate, N, is varied from 20 to 40, depending on the cell size and the charge on the counterion. 3. Results Here we compare our results with the MC data for a micellar system of a~=2O A, a~=2 A, Z2= 12, Z~= 1 and 2, and Cm (apparent monomer concentration) = 694 1.41 mM. To compare our results using point par- ticles with the MC results, we set a,,.. = 11 A in our calculation. For the salt-free system, the Coulomb repulsion compensates for the hard-core interaction, so that the error caused by the omission of the hard core is small [7]. Fig. 1 shows a contour plot of the pair distribution function g,, (r1, r2) for monovalent counterions, with 79 Volume 154, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6 January 1989 20 20 L. 10 10 0 0 r(A) 20 0< L. 10 Fig. 1. A contour plot of the two-particle distribution function g11 (r1, r2) for munovalent counterions, with r1 = 11.1, 16.4, and 23.9 A. The polyion charge is Z,,= 12, the radius of closest ap U Q proach is c~,,= 11 A, and the apparent monomer concentration is r (A) cm=344mM(r,=24A). r, = 11.1, 16.4, and 23.9 A, and Cm 344 mM (r,= 24 A). Here we should note that the correlation length (the maximum distance r~ r2 for which g,, (r,, rz) is markedly different from O) is comparable to the polyion and cell size. This enables us to truncate the summation of eq. (9) at quite low values of 1. For a much larger polyion, we must include higher / values in the expansion and the calculation will get correspondingly harder. Fig. 2 shows the ion distribution function for mono- and di-valent counterions. The PB results are also plot- ted for comparison. The AHNC value is enhanced near a polyion surface and suppressed at the cell boundary; this feature is more pronounced in the system of divalent counterions. Lastly, let us compare the osmotic pressure with the MC results. The pressure is obtained in two different ways. It can be defined by the one-particle density at the cell boundary [6] P4=kTn(r,) (17) or alternatively deduced from the virial theorem (18) ssE~ = fn(r)up..(r)dr+iJdr,Jdr2n(r,,r2)u(Ir,_r21) . (19) These AHNC pressures are given in table 1, together with the PB and MC values. AHNC gives improved results 10 20 r(A) 10 20 10 20 80 Volume 154, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6 January 1989 0.0 12 16 20 r(A) Fig. 2. The one-particle density n(r) for the monovalent (a) and divalent (b) counterions calculated with the AHNC (solid line) and PB models (dashed line). The other parameters are the same as those in fig. 1. compared to PB, especially for the system of divalent eounterions. Here we should note that the MC simulation was done for the canonical ensemble, while the AHNC equation is based on the grand canonical ensemble. This may cause the difference in the correlation function. To estimate this difference, we also include in table 1 the fluctuation of the total number of counterions <(N.. <N..) )2>I/2(JJ n(r,) n(r2) h(r,, r2) dr, dr2+Nc) (20) where < > denotes an average value. To summarise, we have applied the recently introduced AHNC approximation to the spherical cell model, and obtained an osmotic pressure with this approximation in good agreement with the MC results, especially for a system of divalent counterions. head.ce:title: Avoiding the integral storage bottleneck in LCAO calculations of electron correlation

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry and Supercomputer Institute, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, USA

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: Permanent address: Chemistry Department, Mississippi State University, MS 39762, USA.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We propose a method for obtaining electron-repulsion integrals over a molecular-orbital basis without any explicit four-index transformation involving input/output. The approach is in the spirit of our direct SCF scheme in that it uses reevaluation of atomic integrals to allow for calculations that would otherwise be prohibited by storage limitations with conventional techniques. We present correlation energy calculations with up to 318 basis functions using the proposed approach.
